articles.title: UK scientists in EU funding limbo after Boris Johnson's resignation

articles.title: Hurricane that hit Jamaica helped low-lying trees spread to mountains
articles.description: Hurricane Gilbert struck Jamaica in 1988, and the damage it left in its wake might have allowed warm-adapted trees that normally grow at low altitudes to take root on the island’s mountains
articles.content:
By Joshua Rapp Learn
An aeroplane in Jamaica damaged by Hurricane Gilbert – the storm also influenced the island’s ecology

articles.title: UK was worst in Europe for heat pump installations in 2021
articles.description: Just 1.48 heat pumps were installed per 1000 UK households in 2021, despite the devices being seen as a key way to replace gas boilers and reduce emissions
articles.content:

articles.title: Tiny bubbles in semen could contribute to ‘unexplained infertility’
articles.description: A small study in men suggests tiny bubbles of cell membrane found in semen are different in those with unexplained infertility issues compared to those with no fertility problems, which could help explain the mysterious condition
articles.content:
A microscopic image of the seminiferous tubules, the site of sperm production, of a man with infertility issues
CNRI / SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

articles.title: James Webb Space Telescope’s first deep-field image is stunning
articles.description: The first science image from the James Webb Space Telescope, presented by US president Joe Biden on 11 July, is the deepest and highest-resolution infrared image of the universe ever captured

articles.title: Can particles really be in two places at the same time?
articles.description: When talking about quantum physics, people will often nonchalantly say that particles can be in two places at once. Physicist Sabine Hossenfelder explores what is actually going on

articles.title: Men may eat more in summer because sunlight makes them hungrier
